reviewText: I bought this to get The Hound of the Baskervilles, but was delighted with Pursuit to Algiers.  Both are wonderfully acted films and that I hadn't seen in years.  Basil Rathbone was the perfect choice to play Holmes and it is hard for me to watch anyone else in that role.  The are older films, made during the late 1930's and early 1940's and are black and white. Having said that, I would stand them up against any of today's films.  They didn't need the technology and F/X of modern films, rather they let one use their imagination and for that reason will always stand the test of time.  I whole heartedly recommend both films to anyone who loves a good mystery.
summary: I love Basil Rathbone as Sherlock Holmes
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was a gift to a friend who's just discovered the Sherlock Holmes of A. Conan Doyle, as opposed to the modernized incarnations that seem to be gaining popularity. And before all the purists descend on me, I'm quite aware that Nigel Bruce's interpretation of Dr. John Watson was quite different from Doyle's description of the good doctor. However, this film version of "The Hound of the Baskervilles" somehow captures the mood and essence of Doyle's creation better than almost any other (with the possible exception of the BBC version for television with Jeremy Britt as Holmes). Perhaps it's just me, but I find the black-and-white more suitable to the moody, foggy, and frequently sinister Victorian England. And let's face it, the production values of this film are simply top-notch. It's a classic re-telling of a classic tale to be viewed more for what it is than for what it is not.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The two movies in this collection are the first and last Sherlock Holmes movies starring  Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce.  The Hound of the Baskervilles was made at Fox and is filmed in the 1890's time period.  Basil & Nigel did one more film together at Fox: (The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes(also set in the 1890's).Then a few years later the duo moved over to Universal and filmed 12 Sherlock Holmes movies together (set in the 1940's), with Pursuit to Algiers being the last one.  I recently watched the new Sherlock Holmes series on BBC:Sherlock: Season One&Sherlock: Season Twostarring Benedict Cumberbatch, and I loved them.  But that got me to start thinking about how many Basil Rathbone Sherlock movies I had on hand.  Turns out I only had 8 of the 14, and I was missing both The Hound and Pursuit.  This DVD fit my needs very well.  I'll pick up the other four I am missing and life will be good.  While I enjoy the new BBC series, fans need to be aware that the new stories are all based on the original stories (just modernized of course).  I just watched The Hound last night and it was pretty darn good.  Deerstalker hat and all!
summary: The First & Last Sherlock Films with Basil & Nigel

reviewText: All of these MPI Sherlock Holmes two-fers are available at WalMart for an astonishingly low $9.00 each, almost half of what Amazon is charging. They can be hard to find, though. I found them on an endcap facing the wall of TV's.Regarding the restoration, these look pretty good. The original film was cleaned up, but not to the point of perfection, like the Charlie Chan films. There's still a lot of Saturday matinee character.

reviewText: THE HOUND OF THE BASKERVILLES is probably the story most associated with Sherlock Holmes and this version of it is excellent, of course.  It's beautifully photographed and well-constructed.  PURSUIT TO ALGIERS takes place on a ship filled with fog and atmosphere and what old-school mystery fan doesn't like a fog-shrouded mystery cruise?  DVD quality is excellent and the packaging in slip case is especially attractive.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: The five stars are for THE HOUND OF THE BASKERVILLES, still the best version of the story.  Changes to the plot were minor, and it was the first time in the 1930's Holmes was in the correct time period.  The only things to criticize about it were the lack of a music score and Richard Greene receiving top billing.  The sets were excellent, and the villain not being shown captured or killed is how Doyle wrote it.  PURSUIT TO ALGIERS is one of the weaker films in the series.  Holmes  does very little detecting, and the idea that the villains would not know what the true king looked like never made sense.  But at least this time Nigel Bruce got to do a few things on his own, even singing "Loch Lomond"!  Worth it for THE HOUND alone.
summary: One Classic, One Not so Classic

reviewText: Overall, a first-class job... very good productions, full of heart and character, just as all of the Rathbone/Bruce S.H. movies have.  Sharp crystal-clear film-transfers, too.  But as some other reviewers mention, the "Hound" episode does deviate a LOT from the original story (although the film is interesting in its own way).  Also, whoever wrote the DVD subtitles for these two movies obviously didn't listen very closely to what was actually being said before he typed in the dialogue; many important words are wrong, and in some cases, the wording that appears makes no sense at all --- it's just meaningless gibberish.  But if you have fairly good hearing, and you have loudspeakers that reproduce higher frequencies crisply and cleanly, you should be able to understand most if not all of the actors' words just by listening, and so you probably won't need to turn on the subtitles, anyway.  A pleasure to watch.  Recommended.
